questions.text: Modified BPS consists of ?
questions.solution:
Modified Biophysical Score:

Only 2 parameters are included in biophysical score that are NST and AFI. 

Biophysical score(BPS)/ Manning score:

  • It consists of 5 variables.
  • Parameters are observed for a period of  30 mins.
  • Each parameter has a maximum score of 2 and minimum score of 0.
  • So the total maximum score will be 10.
Parameter Normal criteria of score 2
Non stress test Reactive pattern
Fetal breathing movements ≥1 episode lasting  > 30 second
Gross body movements ≥3 discrete body/limb movements
Fetal muscle tone ≥1 episode of active extension (limb or trunk) with return of flexion; opening and closing of hand, considered normal
Amniotic fluid ≥1 pocket measuring 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 × 2 cm pocket)
Score Interpretation
8- 10 Normal
6-7 Equivocal
≤5 Abnormal-  suspect asphyxia

questions.text: Blood flow in the inter-villous space at term is?
questions.solution:
Blood flow in the inter-villous space at term is 500-600ml/min.

Blood flow in inter villous space at term 500-600 mL/min
Nonpregnant uterine blood flow 50 mL/min
Volume of blood in mature placenta 500 mL
Volume of blood in inter villous space 150 mL

questions.text: Peak level of plasma progesterone  in the luteal phase
questions.solution:
Serum value of progesterone is less than 1 ng/ mL in follicular phase and 5–15 ng/mL in midluteal phase.

So peak level of  plasma progesterone in luteal phase is 15 ng/ml.

Hormone Folllicular phase At ovulation Luteal phase
Estradiol (pg/mL) 50 300-600 150-200
Progesterone (ng/mL) <1   5-15
FSH (mIU/mL) 10 15-20 10
LH (mIU/mL) 5 60 5

questions.text: On doing P/V examination of a women about to deliver, anterior fontanelle and supra orbital ridge are palpable. Which among the following will be the engaging diameter of this presentation?
questions.solution:
• In the given question the palpable part in P/V  of a multiparous woman are supraorbital ridge and anterior fontanelle, then it represents Brow presentation.
  • The engaging diameter in brow presentation is Mento vertical, which is about 13.5-14 cm.

In the given image,

A - Submentobregmatic

B - Suboccipitobregmatic

C - Mento vertical

D - Occipito frontal

questions.text: HSG findings in tubercular salpingitis are all except?
questions.solution:
Powder burn appearance is seen in endometriosis, not in tuberculosis.

HSG findings in tubercular salpingitis are:

  • A rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (lead pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in the filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube, coiling of the tubes
  • Cornual block
  • A jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx
  • Vascular or lymphatic extravasation of dye
  • Tubal diverticula and/or fluffiness of tubal outline.
  • Uterine cavity—irregular outline, honeycomb appearance or presence of uterine synechiae

questions.text: The sign seen in the USG image given is seen in ?
questions.solution:
The image represents Spalding sign which is seen in Intra uterine death

Spalding sign :

The irregular overlapping  of the cranial bones on one another is due to  liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault. It usually appears 7 days after death.

Other signs seen in IUD:

  • Robert’s sign- Gas in great vessels of fetus- After 12 hours of death
  • Ball sign- Hyperflexion / hyperextension of spine- After 3-4 weeks of death

questions.text: True about Stein–Leventhal syndrome are all except:
questions.solution:
Stein-Leventhal syndrome is not associated with BRCA1.

Polycystic Ovarian Disease:

  • Also called Stein-Leventhal syndrome.
  • It is seen in young females of the age group 15-25 years mainly.
  • Enlarged ovary with thickened tunica albuginea and associated with theca cell hypertrophy and multiple follicular cysts on the ovarian surface.

Endocrinological changes are as follows:

  • E2/E1 is reduced.
  • FSH/LH ratio falls. (LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL).
  • SHBG level falls due to hyperandrogenism.
  • Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin, 4.5 suggests insulin resistance.
  • Raised Triglyceride level.
  • Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism).

Two of the following three criteria are required:

  • Oligo/amenorrhoea, anovulation
  • Hyperandrogenism
    • clinical (hirsutism or less commonly male pattern alopecia) or
    • biochemical (raised FAI or free testosterone)
  • Polycystic ovaries on ultrasound

questions.text: The maneuver given in the image below is ?
questions.solution:
The image represents Ritgen’s maneuver.

Ritgen’s maneuver:

  • Delivery of a child's head by pressure on the perineum while controlling the speed of delivery by pressure with the other hand on the head.
  • Gloved hand is used to exert pressure on the chin of the fetus through the perineum just in front of the coccyx allows controlled delivery of fetal head and favours extension of the fetal head.
  • This is done in cases of normal vaginal delivery.

Modified Ritgen maneuver:

Moderate upward pressure is applied to the fetal chin by the posterior hand covered with a sterile towel, while the suboccipital region of the fetal head is held against the symphysis.

Prague , Bracht and loveset’s maneuver are used in breech delivery.

questions.text: In testicular feminization syndrome:
questions.solution:
Testicular feminization syndrome is associated with normal breast development.

Testicular feminization syndrome:

  • The condition is inherited as a X-linked recessive gene.
  • The underlying pathology is the inability of the end organs to respond to androgens.
  • Usually presents with primary amenorrhea and or infertility.
  • They are phenotypically and psychologically female.
  • Breast development is adequate.
  • There is eunuchoidal tendency (long arms, big hands and feet).
  • Absent or sparse axillary and pubic hair.
  • External genitalia looks female.
  • Vagina is short and blind .The upper two-thirds of vagina, uterus and tubes are absent due to the effect of AMH. The gonads (Sertoli cells) secrete AMH (Anti-Müllerian hormone).
  • Gonads (testes) are either placed in the labia, or inguinal canal or intra-abdominal
  • Investigation:
    • Sex chromatin is negative.
    • Karyotype is 46, XY.
    • Confirmation of diagnosis is by gonadal biopsy -
      • Seminiferous tubules are small, hyalinized.
      • Spermatogenesis is absent.
      • Leydig cells and Sertoli cells are normal.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the image given below?

choices.text: Associated with obliteration of small muscular arteries in placental tertiary villi
Indicates reversal of end diastolic blood flow

questions.solution:
• The image indicates reversal of end diastolic flow in Doppler of uterine artery.
  • Pregnancy should be terminated in that case not to be continued till term.
  • Reversal of end-diastolic flow has been associated with greater than 70-percent obliteration of the small muscular arteries in placental tertiary stem villi.
  • It is an indication for termination of pregnancy irrespective of gestation age.

Ratios measured by Doppler include:

  • Systolic/ Diastolic index
  • Pulsatality index
  • Resistance index

Abnormal flow patterns in Doppler:

  • Reversed end diastolic flow
  • Reduced end diastolic flow
  • Absent end diastolic flow

 

The image given below shows doppler recordings from umbilical artery(UA), middle cerebral artery (MCA) and aortic isthmus (AoI) and the three intrauterine growth restricted(IUGR) fetuses with present end diastolic flow(PEDF), absent end diastolic flow(AEDF), reverse end diastolic flow(REDF).

questions.text: Head to body delivery time in shoulder dystocia is
questions.solution:
Head to body delivery time in shoulder dystocia- >60s

Head to body delivery time:

  • The mean head-to-body delivery time in normal births -24 seconds
  • It was proposed that a head-to-body delivery time > 60 seconds be used to define shoulder dystocia.
  • Currently, however, the diagnosis continues to rely on the clinical perception that the normal downward traction needed for fetal shoulder delivery is ineffective.

questions.text: What is the approximate weight of the fetus , if the height of the uterus above pubic symphysis is about 35cm and station of head -2?
questions.solution:
Estimation of fetal weight using Johnsons formula:

If station of fetal head is below the ischial spine

  • Fetal weight = (Ht of uterus above pubic symphysis [in cms] – 11) ⨯155

If station of fetal head is at or above ischial spine

  • Fetal weight = (Ht of uterus above pubic symphysis [in cms] – 12) ⨯155

In the given question, the station of head= -2 ,  is Above the ischial spine,

Height of uterus above pubic  symphysis = 35 cm

hence,

Fetal weight = (35-12) ⨯155    = 23⨯155    = 3,565 gm

Approximate weight = 3.5 kg.

questions.text: The pain in endometriosis mainly correlates with:
questions.solution: • The Depth of penetration is more related to symptoms rather than the spread. Lesions penetrating more than 5mm are responsible for pain, dysmenorrhea, and dyspareunia.

questions.text: Deep transverse arrest is seen in all except ____________
questions.solution:
Transverse lie indicates presenting part is shoulder hence there will be no case of deep transverse arrest of head.

Deep transverse arrest:

The head is deep into the cavity; the sagittal suture is placed in the transverse bispinous diameter and there is no progress in descent of the head even after ½–1 hour following full dilatation of the cervix.

Causes:

  • Faulty pelvic architecture such as prominent ischial spines, flat sacrum and convergent side walls - android pelvis
  • Deflexion of the head
  • Weak uterine contraction- uterine inertia
  • Laxity of the pelvic floor muscles- Epidural analgesia (prolonged 2nd stage of labour)

Diagnosis:

  • The head is engaged
  • The sagittal suture lies in the transverse bispinous diameter
  • Anterior fontanel is palpable
  • Faulty pelvic architecture may be detected.

Management:

  • Vaginal delivery is found not safe (big baby and or inadequate pelvis): Cesarean section.
  • Vaginal delivery is found safe (any of the methods may be employed)
    • Ventouse—Excessive traction force should not be used
    • Manual rotation and application of forceps
    • Forceps rotation and delivery with Kielland in the hands of an expert.

questions.text: Vaginal epithelium is derived from
questions.solution:
Vaginal epithelium is derived from Endoderm of  urogenital sinus

Development of vagina:

Vagina is derived from mullerian duct and urogenital sinus.

  • Upper 3/5th is derived from mullerian duct while lower part is derived from Urogenital sinus.
  • Junction of mullerian duct and urogenital sinus forms the Hymen.
  • Urogenital sinus endoderm forms the epithelium of vagina and portio vaginalis part of cervix.
  • Ectoderm of genital folds form the vaginal introitus.

questions.text: In the etiology of endometriosis, Sampson’s theory is:
questions.solution:
Sampson’s retrograde menstruation/implantation theory:

  • It attributes endome­triosis to reflux of menstrual endometrium through the fallopian tubes and its subsequent implantation and growth on the pelvic peritoneum and the surrounding structures.
  • It is associated with hypotonia of Utero tubal junction.
  • The occurrence of scar endometriosis following classical caesarean section, hysterotomy, myomectomy and episiotomy and the occurrence of endometriosis in young girls with cryptomenorrhoea, and retrograde collection of menstrual fluid further supports this view.

Meyer and Ivanoff’s Coelomic metaplasia theory:

  • Mullerian tissue remnants trapped within the peritoneum undergo metaplasia and get transformed to endometrial tissue.

Halban’s metastatic theory:

  • Embolisation of menstrual frag­ments through vascular or lymphatic channels occur, and this leads to the launching of endometriosis at distal sites like umbi­licus, pelvic lymph nodes, ureter, rectovaginal septum, bowel wall, and remote sites like the lung, pleura, endo­cardium and the extremities.

Hormonal theory:

  • It is an estrogen-dependent condition. Cyclical hormones stimulate its growth, but continuous hormone secretion or therapy suppresses it.
  • It is rare before menarche and after menopause.
  • Pregnancy causes atrophy of endometriosis chiefly through high progesterone levels. Regression also follows oophorectomy and irradiation.
  • Hormones with anti-estrogenic activity also suppress endometriosis and are used therapeutically.
  • Smoking reduces estrogen level and thereby the incidence of endo­metriosis proliferation.

Immunological Factor:

  • Impaired T cell and NK cell activity and altered immunology in a woman may increase the susceptibility to proliferation and growth.

Genetic basis:

  • It accounts for 10% of endometriosis; inci­dence in the first-degree relative is sevenfold.

questions.text: Which of these is diagnostic of menopause?
questions.solution:
Serum FSH>40 mIU/mL  is diagnostic feature of Menopause.

Diagnostic criteria for menopause based on hormone  levels include:

Estrogen(E2) 5-25 pg/mL
Estrone(E1) 20-70 pg/mL
E2/E1 ratio <1
FSH >40 mIU/mL
LH 50-100 mIU/mL

questions.text: Gartner’s cyst can be differentiated from cystocoele by A/E:

choices.text: Presence of rugosities of overlying vaginal mucosa

questions.solution:
Rugosities of the overlying vaginal mucosa are lost in a case of Gartner’s cyst.

Gartner’s cyst:

Gartner’s cyst is the retention cyst in remnants of Wolffian duct.

 

Features of Gartner’s cyst are:

  • Situated anteriorly or anterolaterally and of variable sizes.
  • Rugosities of the overlying vaginal mucosa are lost.
  • Vaginal mucosa over it becomes tense and shiny.
  • Margins are well-defined.
  • It is not reducible.
  • There is no impulse on coughing.
  • The metal catheter tip introduced per urethra fails to come underneath the vaginal mucosa

Cystocoele is a reducible  with cough impulse without well defined margins and presence of rugosities.

questions.text: What is the most symptomatic type of fibroid?
questions.solution: • The submucous fibroid is the least common type but produces maximum symptoms.

questions.text: The Uterine anomaly shown in the image given below falls under which category of the AFS  Classification of Mullerian duct anomalies?
questions.solution:
The image given is that of Arcuate uterus which falls under Type VI of AFS classification of mullerian duct anomalies.

Arcuate uterus – Flat topped with lack of fundal bulge.

Class Anomaly
I Mullerian agenesis (MRKH syndrome)/ hypoplasia
II Unicornuate uterus
III Didelphys uterus
IV Bicornuate uterus
V Septate uterus
VI Arcuate uterus
VII DES related abnormalities

questions.text: Indications of myomectomy are all except:
questions.solution:
Indications of myomectomy are

  • Persistent uterine bleeding despite medical therapy
  • Excessive pain or pressure symptoms
  • Size >12weeks, woman desirous to have a baby
  • Unexplained infertility with distortion of uterine cavity due to fibroid
  • Recurrent pregnancy wastage due to fibroid
  • Rapidly growing myoma during follow-up
  • Subserous pedunculated fibroid.

Red degeneration is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy and usually managed conservatively with bed rest and analgesics.

questions.text: Halban’s disease is due to ?
questions.solution:
Halban’s Disease  is due to per­sistent corpus luteum.

Halban’s Disease:

  • Represents Irregular Shedding
  • It is rare and self-limited. 
  • Irregular shedding is due to per­sistent corpus luteum due to Incomplete withdrawal of LH even on 26th day of cycle.
  • The menstruation comes on time, is prolonged but not heavy.
  • Progestogen can suppress the bleeding, but needs to be taken on tapering dose for 20 days to complete the cycle.
  • Treatment: Spontaneous cure / NSAIDs for 6 months.

questions.text: While evaluating a patient with secondary amenorrhoea, you administer her estrogen and progesterone. However, withdrawal bleeding is not seen. What is the likely site of lesion here?
questions.solution:
The absence of withdrawal bleeding after the estrogen-progesterone challenge test points towards a local endometrial lesion.

Estrogen–progesterone challenge test is indicated as an investigation in case of secondary amenorrhea. It depends on estrogen-primed endometrium being present in the uterus. 

Procedure:

  • Ethinyl estradiol 0.02 mg or conjugated equine estrogen 1.25 mg is to be taken daily for 25 days.
  • Medroxyprogesterone acetate 10 mg daily is added from day 15–25.
  • Alternately, one course of oral contraceptive pill is given and to observe whether withdrawal bleeding occurs or not.

Results:

  • If there is no bleeding, a local endometrial lesion is present such as uterine synechiae. This is to be confirmed by HSG or hysteroscopy.
  • If withdrawal bleeding occurs, the endometrium is responsive but the endogenous estrogen production is inadequate. Hence, the defect lies in the ovary, hypothalamus, or pituitary.

questions.text: A pregnant woman with fibroid uterus develops acute pain in abdomen with low-grade fever and leucocytosis at 28 weeks. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Red degeneration of fibroid is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. It presents with acute pain abdomen, vomiting. Leucocytosis and raised ESR will be evident. 
  • Option B: Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen but fever and leucocytosis are absent.
  • Option C: Infection is more common in Puerperium and presents with blood stained discharge.
  • Option D: Preterm labor – there is no mention of uterine contractions or cervical findings.

questions.text: Infibulation comes under which type of WHO Classification of Female Genital Mutilation?
questions.solution:
Infibulation comes under  type  III of WHO Classification of Female Genital Mutilation.

Female Genital Mutilation:

Inaccurately called female circumcision, mutilation refers to medically unnecessary vulvar and perineal modification.

The World Health Organization  classifies genital mutilations into four types.

 

Type Feature
I Prepuce excision with or without clitoral excision
II Clitoral excision with or without partial or total labia minora excision
III Partial or complete labial minora and/or majora excision with or without clitoridectomy and then fusion of the wound, termed infibulation.
IV Unclassified and includes pricking, piercing, incision, stretching, and introduction of  corrosive substances into the vagina

questions.text: Diagnostic criteria for primary abdominal pregnancy is
questions.solution:
The criteria laid down by Studdiford is used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancy.

Site of pregnancy Criteria Management
Primary abdominal pregnancy

Studdiford's criteria

  • Both the tubes and ovaries should be normal
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula
  • Pregnancy must be exclusively related to the peritoneal surface 
 Surgical management
Ovarian pregnancy

Spiegelberg's criteria

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • Gestational sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • Gestational sac connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall
 Surgical management
Cervical pregnancy

Rubin's criteria (Palmatic's criteria)

  • The uterus is smaller than surrounding distended cervix
  • Internal os is not dilated
  • Curettage of the endometrial cavity is nonproductive of placental tissue
  • External os opens earlier than in spontaneous abortion
  • Medical management if vitals are stable
  • Surgical management if vitals are unstable

questions.text: True statement regarding pelvic tuberculosis is

choices.text: Almost always secondary to primary infection elsewhere in the body
Hematogenous spread is the most common route of spread
Fallopian tubes are most commonly affected

questions.solution:
• Genital tuberculosis is almost always secondary to primary infection elsewhere.
  • Most common primary focus in genital TB is lungs.
  • Most common mode of spread is haematogenous.
  • Most common organ to be affected and first organ to be affected is fallopian tubes.

questions.text: The USG given below is seen in
questions.solution:
The above image shows the characteristic snow storm appearance seen in hydatidiform mole.

Hydatidiform Mole is principally a disease of the chorion. Death of the ovum or failure of the embryo to grow is essential to develop complete (classic) hydatidiform mole. The secretion from the hyperplastic cells and transferred substances from the maternal blood accumulate in the stroma of the villi which results in distension of the villi to form small vesicles.

Classical clinical feature of a complete mole:

  • Abnormal vaginal bleeding
  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Features of early onset preeclampsia < 20 weeks
  • Uterus > dates (50%)
  • Absent fetal parts and FHS
  • Expulsion of vesicular tissues
  • Theca lutein cyst of ovaries (25%) > 6 cm
  • Hyperthyroidism (rare)
  • Serum hCG > 100,000 mIU/mL
  • USG: snowstorm appearance

questions.text: Identify the abnormality in the given picture.
questions.solution:
The above image depicts caudal regression syndrome.

The caudal regression syndrome is a rare malformation but is frequently associated with maternal diabetes. It consists of a spectrum of structural defects of the caudal region, including incomplete development of the sacrum and the lumbar vertebrae.

It occurs approximately 200 times more frequently in infants of diabetic mothers than in other infants.

questions.text: The following primary tumors are common in the vulva except
questions.solution:
The primary tumor not common in vulva is choriocarcinoma

Histological types of vulval cancers are:

  • Squamous cell carcinoma–90%
  • Melanoma 5%
  • Adenocarcinoma (bartholin’s gland)
  • basal cell carcinoma
  • Sarcoma

questions.text: Childbirth trauma leading to urine incontinence is seen least in females with
questions.solution:
Childbirth trauma injury is more common in gynecoid and least in android pelvis.

The android pelvis has a narrow pubic arch and this is protective against childbirth trauma injury and pelvic organ prolapse compared to the gynecoid pelvis.

Childbirth trauma causes damage of the pelvic floor and pubocervical fascia and leads to denervation of the smooth and striated components of the sphincter.

questions.text: Absolute proof of monozygosity is determined by
questions.solution:
The most definite proof of monozygosity is DNA finger printing by DNA microprobe technique

The difference between monozygotic and dizygotic twins are:

Variables Monozygotic Dizygotic
Placenta One Two (most often fused)
Communicating vessels Present Absent
Intervening membrane 2 (amnios) 4 (2 amnios 2 chorios)
Sex Always identical May differ
Genetic features (dominant blood group) DNA finger printing Same Differ
Skin grafting (reciprocal) Acceptance Rejection
Follow-up Usually identical Not identical

questions.text: Dose of anti-D for antenatal prophylaxis in Rh negative nonimmunized females

choices.text: Single dose of 1000 IU at 28 weeks
Single dose of 1500 IU at 28 weeks
Single dose of 500 IU at 28 weeks
Single dose of 1500 IU at 32 weeks

questions.solution:
The above question refers to antenatal prophylaxis which is a single dose of 1500IU (or 300mcg) at 28 weeks.

To prevent active immunization of Rh-negative yet unimmunized, Rh anti-D immunoglobulin (IgG) is administered intramuscularly to the mother following childbirth, in spite of which the failure rate is about 1–2%. This is due to antepartum feto-maternal hemorrhage and sensitization (1–2%).

If the woman is Rh-negative and has no antibody, she should have one dose of 300 µg Rh immune globulin as prophylaxis at around 28 weeks (ACOG–1999) and again after birth (within 72 hours).

To minimize or prevent the feto-maternal bleed:

  • Precaution during C section
  • Prophylactic ergometrine should preferably be withheld, as it may facilitate more fetoplacental bleed
  • Amniocentesis should be done after sonographic localization of the placenta to prevent its injury
  • Amniocentesis should be done after sonographic localization of the placenta to prevent its injury
  • Manual removal of placenta should be done gently
  • To refrain from abdominal palpation as far as possible in abruptio placentae.

Postpartum prophylaxis in Rh-negative mother:

  • Rh anti-D is administered intramuscularly to the mother following childbirth or abortion.
  • To be administered within 72 hours or preferably earlier following delivery or abortion.
  • Should be given only if baby born is Rh +ve and Direct Coombs test done on baby's blood is negative.
  • In case 72 hours are over, it can be given up to 28 days after delivery to avoid sensitization.

Dose:

  • 300mcg(1500IU) following delivery.
  • 300 mcg following induced abortion, ectopic pregnancy, or CVS in 1st trimester.
  • 300 mcg in pregnancy for more than 12 weeks.
  • 300 micrograms(1500IU) is the minimum dose of anti-D which is used for alloimmunization as per recent NICE guidelines.

questions.text: Indications of rectal examination in gynecology are all except
questions.solution:
Rectal examination is not indicated in the staging of ovarian malignancy

Rectal examination can be done in isolation or as an adjunct to vaginal examination.

Indications of Rectal Examination:

  • Children or in adult virgins
  • Painful vaginal examination
  • Carcinoma cervix—to note the parametrial involvement (base of the broad ligament and the uterosacral ligament can only be felt rectally) or involvement of the rectum
  • To corroborate the findings felt in the pouch of Douglas by bimanual vaginal examination
  • Atresia (agenesis) of vagina
  • Patients having rectal symptoms
  • To diagnose rectocele and differentiate it from enterocele.

questions.text: You are performing capillary blood glucose charting for newborns in the post-natal ward. Below what level is it considered hypoglycemia?
questions.solution:
Neonatal hypoglycemia is defined as blood glucose levels <45 mg/dL.

Maternal hyperglycemia stimulates the fetal pancreas to secrete excess insulin, which causes increased neonatal fat deposition, abdominal girth, and macrosomia (Pederson's hypothesis). It also leads to a rapid drop in plasma glucose concentration after delivery.

questions.text: Which of the following heart diseases maternal mortality is found to be highest?
questions.solution:
Maternal mortality is about 50% and so also the perinatal loss (50%) in Eisenmenger's syndrome.

Eisenmenger's syndrome is the presence of secondary pulmonary hypertension that develops from a cardiac lesion. 

The syndrome develops when,

  • It is the heart disease with the worst prognosis during pregnancy with a maternal mortality of 50% . Hence pregnancy is contraindicated in patients of Eisenmenger's syndrome.
  • If the diagnosis of Eisenmenger's is made in the first trimester, termination of pregnancy is advised.
  • Most common cause of death in Eisenmenger's syndrome is right ventricular failure with cardiogenic shock.

questions.text: The following statements are related to Krukenberg tumor except

choices.text: The most common primary site is pylorus of the stomach

questions.solution:
The Krukenberg tumor is a metastatic tumor to the ovary but it may be a primary tumor.

It is an atypical tumor in which the histological picture differs from that of the primary one

The common primary sites from where metastases to the ovaries occur are:

  • gastrointestinal tract (pylorus, colon and rarely small intestine),
  • gallbladder,
  • pancreas,
  • breast
  • endometrial carcinoma

The tumor is usually bilateral, solid with smooth surfaces and usually maintaining the shape of the ovary. They are bosselated and may attain a big size. There is no tendency of adhesion.

Histologically, the stroma is highly cellular. The mucin within epithelial cells compresses the nuclei to one pole, producing ‘signet ring’ appearance which is characteristic.

In most patients with Krukenberg’s tumors, the prognosis is poor. Median survival being less than a year.

questions.text: Cryosurgery is effective in all except

choices.text: Cases with severe dysplasia or CIS lesions

questions.solution:
Cryosurgery is not effective in cases with severe dysplasia or CIS lesions.

Cryosurgery is a procedure whereby destruction of the tissue is effective by freezing.

Indications:

  • Cervical ectopy
  • Benign cervical lesions—such as CIN, condyloma accuminata, leukoplakia, etc.
  • Condyloma accuminata of vulva and VIN diagnosed colposcopically and not more than 2 cm in size.
  • VAIN, condyloma accuminata or vault granulation tissue following hysterectomy.
  • As a palliative measure to arrest bleeding in carcinoma cervix or large fungating recurrent vulval carcinoma.

The priciple of cryosurgery is that freezing produces cellular dehydration by crystallization of intracellular water and ultimately death of cells.

Advantages of cryosurgery over thermal cautery:

  • Anesthesia is not required.
  • Precise destruction of tissue.
  • There is no secondary hemorrhage.
  • Cervical stenosis is rare.

The drawback is excessive discharge for about 2–3 weeks.

Healing is complete in 6-10 weeks.

questions.text: Which type of eclampsia has the worst prognosis?
questions.solution:
Maternal complications are higher in antepartum eclampsia.

Eclampsia associated with the following features has bad prognosis:

  • Long interval between the onset of fit and commencement of treatment (late referral).

          Antepartum eclampsia especially with long delivery interval

  • Number of fits more than ten
  • Coma in between fits.
  • Temperature over 102°F with pulse rate above 120/minute.
  • Blood pressure over 200 mm Hg systolic.
  • Oliguria (< 400 mL/24 hours) with proteinuria > 5 g/24 hours.
  • Nonresponse to treatment.
  • Jaundice.

questions.text: Congenital infection in fetus with minimal teratogenic risk is
questions.solution:
Teratogenic effects have not been documented with HIV infection. In Highly Active Antiretroviral therapy(HAART) , Efavirenz is avoided in the first trimester due to its teratogenic risk.

Effects of HIV

  • On mother:

-The course of HIV in mother remians unaltered as a result of pregnancy

-Maternal mortality or morbidity are not increased by HIV

-Main problems associated with HIV infection during pregnancy are related to preterm delivery and IUGR

  • On fetus:

-No teratogenic effects have been reported

-Preterm delivery, IUGR

No teratogenic effect

  • HIV
  • Measles
  • Influenza
  • Mumps

Infections causing congenital malformations (teratogenic effects)

  • Rubella
  • Varicella
  • CMV
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Parvovirus

questions.text: A pregnant woman presented to the clinic with complaints of dizziness. On examination, pallor was present. She will be considered severely anemic if her hemoglobin is less than _____.
questions.solution:
Severe anemia is defined as Hb < 7 g/dL.

Anemia in pregnancy is said to occur when Hb level is <11 g/dL. It is classified as shown below:

Hemoglobin values (g/dL)  WHO classification of anemia in pregnancy ICMR classification of anemia in pregnancy
≥11

Normal

In the second trimester, Hb ≥10.5 g/dL is considered normal

 Normal
10-10.9 Mild  Mild
7-9.9  Moderate Moderate
<7  Severe Severe
<4   - Very severe

questions.text: Hypokalemic paralysis is a side effect of
questions.solution:
Hypokalemic paralysis is a side effect of Gossypol.

  • Gossypol is a male contraceptive pill  discovered in China from an extract of cotton seed.
  • Mechanism of action : it inhibits spermatogenesis and decreases epididymal sperm motility.
  • Side effect: hypokalemic paralysis, cardiac arrhythmias, fatigue, decreased libido and delayed recovery of sperm count.

questions.text: Which of the following OCP's have the least amount of estrogen?
questions.solution:
Loette is the OCP with the least amount of Estrogen.

Commercial name Composition of Progestins (mg) Composition of Estrogen (mcg) Number of tablets
Mala N Levonorgestrel (0.15) Ethinyl estradiol (30) 21 + 7 iron tablets
Mala D Levonorgestrel (0.15) Ethinyl estradiol (30) 21 + 7 iron tablets
Loette Desogestrel (0.15) Ethinyl estradiol (20) 21
Yasmin Drospirenone 3 mg Ethinyl estradiol (30) 21

Depending on the amount of ethinyl estradiol (E) and the types of progestin (P) used, pills are defined as:

  • 1st generation — with E 50 µg or more
  • 2nd generation — with E 20–35 µg and P as levonorgestrel or norgestimate
  • 3rd generation — with E 20–30 µg and P as desogestrel or gestodene
  • 4th generation — E as third generation, with P as drospirenone, dienogest or nomegestrol.

Low dose pills have E less than 50 µg.

questions.text: The meantime for onset of first menstruation following delivery is
questions.solution:
The onset of the first menstrual period following delivery depends on lactation. If woman does not breastfeed her baby, menstruation returns by 12th in 80% of cases.

The meantime for onset of first menstruation is  7 – 9 weeks.

In nonlactating mothers, ovulation may occur as early as 4 weeks and in lactating mothers about  10 weeks after delivery.

The rule of 3's:

  • In the presence of full breast feeding, a contraceptive method should begin in the 3rd postpartum month.
  • With partial breast feeding or no breast feeding, a contraceptive method should begin during the 3rd postpartum week

questions.text: A G2P1L1 woman at 30 weeks of gestation was rushed to the casualty with complaints of painless vaginal bleeding. She had woken up to find herself in a pool of blood. On examination, her vitals were unstable. Active bleeding per vaginum was present. Which of the following complications would not be anticipated in her?
questions.solution:
Then given clinical scenario is suggestive of placenta previa and precipitate labour is not a complication. Precipitate labour is seen in abruptio placenta and uterine tachysystole.

Vaginal bleeding in placenta previa is sudden in onset, recurrent, painless, unrelated to activity, and often occurs during sleep.

Complications of placenta previa: 

Maternal complications:

Period Complication
Antepartum

Antepartum haemorrhage

Malpresentation

Preterm labour
Intrapartum

Early rupture of membranes

Slow dilatation of cervix
Postpartum Postpartum haemorrhage
Puerperium

Sepsis

Subinvolution

Fetal complications:

  • Low birth weight
  • Asphyxia
  • Intrauterine death
  • Birth injuries
  • Congenital malformations.

questions.text: You are an intern posted in the labor room assisting the delivery of a primigravida in labor. The obstetrician planned for a ventouse delivery because of maternal exhaustion. She asked you to help place the ventouse cup. Where would you place it?

choices.text: On the sagittal suture 3 cm in front of posterior fontanelle
On the sagittal suture 3 cm behind of anterior  fontanelle
On the coronal suture 6 cm away from anterior fontanelle

questions.solution:
An important step in vacuum extraction is proper cup placement over the flexion point. It is a point on the sagittal suture that lies 3 cm in front of the posterior fontanelle.

Advantages of correct positioning of cup in vacuum extraction:

  • Maximum traction
  • Minimum cup detachment
  • Twisting of fetal head is avoided
  • Smallest head diameter is delivered through the pelvic outlet
  • Success rate is improved
  • Fetal scalp injury rates are lowered
  • Perineal trauma is reduced because the smallest fetal head diameter distends the vulva

questions.text: Reliable diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma can be made from all except
questions.solution:
Papanicolaou smear is not a reliable diagnostic test for endometrial carcinoma. It is positive only in 30 percent of cases of endometrial cancer.

Diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma:

  • Endometrial biopsy: using a Sharman curette or a soft, flexible, plastic suction cannula (pipelle) has been done with reliability (90%). Histology is the definitive diagnosis.
  • Ultrasound and color Doppler (TVS):

-Endometrial thickness > 4 mm.

-Hyperechoic endometrium with irregular outline.

-Increased vascularity with low vascular resistance.

-Intrauterine fluid.

  • Hysteroscopy: It helps in the direct visualization of the endometrium and to take target biopsy.
  • Fractional curettage: It is the definitive method of diagnosis and can also detect the extent of growth.

questions.text: In a cervix, low grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (LSIL)in Bethseda system includes:
questions.solution:
In Bethesda system

LSIL = CIN 1

HSIL = CIN 2, CIN 3/Ca in situ

 

Cervical Intraepithelial Neoplasia (CIN) is classified under the Bethesda system (1988) into 3 categories based on the cytological abnormalities of the premalignant lesions.

  • Atypical squamous cells (ASC)
  • Low grade squamous intraepithelial lesions (LSIL)
  • High grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL)

Related Pearl: Grades of cervical dysplasia

A comparison of various naming systems based on cytology (Bethesda) and biopsy (CIN grade)

WHO grade Bethesda CIN grade Description
Mild Dysplasia LSIL CIN I Dysplastic cells in basal 1/3 of cervical epithelium
Moderate Dysplasia HSIL CIN II Dysplastic cells in basal 2/3 of cervical epithelium
Severe dysplasia CIN III Dysplastic cells in >2/3 of the cervical epithelium
Carcinoma in situ Carcinoma in situ Dysplastic cells in full-thickness of cervical epithelium but basement membrane is intact

 

LSIL HSIL
Atypia confined to the basal one-third of the epithelium Atypia involving upper two-third of the epithelium
80% of LSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16 100% of HSILs are associated with high-risk HPVs, mostly HPV-16
60% regress spontaneously; only 10% progress to HSIL. 30% regress spontaneously; 10% progress to carcinoma
Not a premalignant lesion Premalignant lesion
Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy Next step - Colposcopic directed biopsy + Endocervical curettage

Abbreviations:

CIN: Cervical Intra-epithelial neoplasia

LSIL: Low Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

HSIL: High Squamous Intra-epithelial Lesion

questions.text: Ureterovaginal fistula should best be treated by

choices.text: End-to-end anastomosis through an ureteric catheter

questions.solution:
Surgeries for ureteric fistula:

  • Bladder flap procedure (modified Boari-Ocker-Blad)
  • Ureteroileoneocystotomy
  • Implantation into bladder

questions.text: According to the 2010 WHO criteria what are the characteristics of normal semen analysis

choices.text: Volume 1ml, count 10 million/ml, morphology more than 14%, progressive motility more than 32%
Volume 2ml, count 20 million/ml, morphology more than 14%, progressive motility more than 32%
Volume 1ml, count 20 million/ml, morphology more than 14%, progressive motility more than 32%
Volume 2ml, count 10 million/ml, morphology more than 14%, progressive motility more than 32%

questions.solution:
Volume 2ml, sperm count 20 million/ml, morphology more than 14% normal form, progressive motility more than 32% are the characteristics of a normal semen analysis,

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Criteria, Normal values, Lowest reference limits (in brackets)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)
